item.title: The first look at new Paul Goldschmidt Cardinals apparel - SB Nation
item.description:
The first look at new Paul Goldschmidt Cardinals apparel  SB Nation

Fanatics Start repping the newest member of the St. Louis Cardinals. After eight seasons in the desert, Paul Goldschmidt is taking his talents to St. Louis. On Wednesday, the Arizona Diamondbacks traded Goldschmidt to the St. Louis Cardinals for catcher Carson Kelly, pitcher Luke Weaver, infielder Andy Young, and a 2019 draft pick. Goldschmidt, a six-time all-star, brings his power bat to a lineup that hit 205 home runs last season, but missed out on the final Wild Card spot by 2.5 games. Last season, Goldschmidt hit .290/.389/.533 with 33 home runs and 35 doubles in 158 games. Over the pas...

item.title: Cards' Goldschmidt is not thinking beyond 2019 season - The Associated Press
item.description:
Cards' Goldschmidt is not thinking beyond 2019 season  The Associated Press

ST. LOUIS (AP) — Now that he is with the St. Louis Cardinals, Paul Goldschmidt is not thinking beyond 2019 season. The six-time All-Star was acquired from Arizona this week and will earn $14.5 million in the final season of a seven-year deal that will pay $46 million, including a $1 million assignment bonus for the trade. If he doesn't sign a new contract, he would be among the top free agents next offseason. "Try not to have any distractions, so anything like that won't be on my mind," Goldschmidt said at his introductory news conference Friday. "I think the biggest thing is I'm excited to...

item.title: Mozeliak on acquiring Goldschmidt: 'We had to make this happen' - FOX Sports
item.description:
Mozeliak on acquiring Goldschmidt: 'We had to make this happen'  FOX Sports

item.title: Yankees: How far-fetched is deal for a Zack Greinke? - FanSided
item.description:
Yankees: How far-fetched is deal for a Zack Greinke?  FanSided

With Patrick Corbin signing a six-year deal with the Nationals, the Yankees list of starting pitching options has shortened. Could the Bronx Bombers realistically turn their sights toward another pitcher from the desert? The Yankees have made it pretty clear they're "all in" on improving their starting rotation this offseason. However, over the past few days, the Yanks have watched two of the top free agent pitchers, Patrick Corbin and Nathan Eovaldi, sign with other teams. That leaves the Bombers with a decision to make: Sign one of the remaining free agent arms (Dallas Keuchel, J.A. Happ,...

item.title: Mozeliak on Goldy: ‘We couldn’t find anything negative on him’ - FOX Sports
item.description:

item.title: Harper, Machado Not In Cardinals' Plans - International Business Times
item.description:
Harper, Machado Not In Cardinals' Plans  International Business Times

A potential suitor for MLB’s top two free agents appears to be out of the running. After making a trade for Paul Goldschmidt, the St. Louis Cardinals are no longer a realistic landing spot for Bryce Harper or Manny Machado. St. Louis had been looking to make a splash by acquiring one of the game’s best hitters. That came Wednesday when the team sent three players and a draft pick to the Arizona Diamondbacks for their new first basemen. The six-time All-Star is owed $14.5 million on the final year of his contract, and the Cardinals will look to re-sign him instead of throwing money at Harper...

item.title: In a winter of bold moves, Bryce Harper and Manny Machado are still waiting - The Washington Post
item.description:
In a winter of bold moves, Bryce Harper and Manny Machado are still waiting  The Washington Post

Where will Manny Machado end up? (Patrick Semansky/Associated Press)The Associated Press It takes a certain resolve to trade away the best position player in your franchise’s history, coming off a season in which you contended until mid-September, but that’s what the Arizona Diamondbacks did Wednesday in sending first baseman Paul Goldschmidt to the St. Louis Cardinals for prospects and draft picks. It takes a certain boldness to guarantee six years and $140 million to a pitcher with one transcendent season on his resume, but that’s what the Washington Nationals did in signing lefty Patrick...

item.title: Greinke Up Next After Goldschmidt Trade - International Business Times
item.description:
Greinke Up Next After Goldschmidt Trade  International Business Times

The Arizona Diamondbacks have begun to rebuild by dealing arguably the best position player in the history of the franchise. The team agreed to trade Paul Goldschmidt to the St. Louis Cardinals Wednesday, and it will likely be the first of a few moves for the organization this offseason. Now that Goldschmidt is gone, Arizona will look to trade Zack Greinke. The Diamondbacks are hoping to get rid of the starting pitcher and the $106.5 million he’s owed over the next three years. Goldschmidt is set to become a free agent after the 2019 MLB season. Moving Greinke won’t be easy. The 35-year-old...

item.title: Chicago Cubs: Paul Goldschmidt to the Cardinals shifts the Central - FanSided
item.description:
Chicago Cubs: Paul Goldschmidt to the Cardinals shifts the Central  FanSided

Everyone is focused on the Chicago Cubs and Milwaukee Brewers, but the St. Louis Cardinals are back in the mix after landing slugger Paul Goldschmidt. The St. Louis Cardinals are the first National League Central team to strike this offseason, landing slugger Paul Goldschmidt via trade. The Cardinals will send pitcher Luke Weaver, catcher Carson Kelly, minor league infielder Andy Young and a compensation draft pick to the Arizona Diamondbacks in the deal. Wrigley Field has a new villain. After seeing the Chicago Cubs get the best of the rival Cardinals for the past three seasons, St. Louis ...
